newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech budget vote seen delayed by long debate.
newsitem.headline: Czech budget vote seen delayed by long debate.

text.p: The Czech parliament is unlikely to vote on the first reading of the state budget on Tuesday, as a long line of deputies take turns speaking on the subject, a senior parliamentarian told Reuters on Tuesday.
"I doubt that the approval will come today, and the debate will be very, very long," Milan Uhde, parliamentary club chairman of Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus's Civic Deomcratic Party (ODS), said.

The lower chamber of parliament was expected to hold the first reading of the draft budget later on Tuesday, but the opposition Social Democrats have said they would seek changes to two paragraphs in the draft.
The far-right Republican Party (SPR-RSC) and the little-reformed Communists (KSCM) are also expected to give lengthy speeches that could delay the vote.
Klaus's three-party coalition holds only 99 seats in the 200-seat chamber. The Social Democrats can therefore block the budget if they win full support from the Communists and Republicans.
